---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body: An issue I see is that we currently don't have Radon-Nikodym for `μ ≪ ν` without any assumption on `μ` (or even for `μ` s-finite). Right now we have it under the hypothesis of the two measures having a Lebesgue decomposition, and we have the existence of that decomposition only when they are *both* sigma-finite. My plan is to deduce the more general RN theorem from this PR (and several other PRs to come, proving among others the existence of the rho in your argument).

But do you agree that in the end the result should be true without any assumption? In this case, it could we worth adding a TODO in the docstring, and using a lemma name showing more clearly that it is an auxiliary statement towards a more general result. If you only use it with measurable functions, I am also not sure it's worth stating the auxiliary result for ae-measurable functions.

Yes I agree that it is true more generally! I will add a TODO and keep only the result for measurable instead of ae-measurable for now.
This auxiliary lemma will then be used to prove that every measure absolutely continuous with respect to an s-finite measure is s-finite, and at that point I'll come back to this to add an instance for s-finiteness of `μ.withDensity f`.

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8983731956/job/24674101001)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8983731956/job/24674100608)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8983731956/job/24674100800)

You have an assumption that `f` is ae-measurable in your last lemma. Do you think it is really necessary? Sketch of proof without it (I haven't checked the details, so maybe I am saying nonsense): `μ.withDensity f` is absolutely continuous with respect to `μ`, which is absolutely continuous wrt to a finite measure rho. By Radon-Nikodym, one may write `μ.withDensity f` as a measure with density wrt rho, with some measurable density. And then you can apply your first lemma.

You have an assumption that `f` is ae-measurable in your last lemma. Do you think it is really necessary? Sketch of proof without it (I haven't checked the details, so maybe I am saying nonsense): `μ.withDensity f` is absolutely continuous with respect to `μ`, which is absolutely continuous wrt to a finite measure rho. By Radon-Nikodym, one may write `μ.withDensity f` as a measure with density wrt rho, with some measurable density. And then you can apply your first lemma.
I think enabling dot notation with `Measure.sFinite_withDensity` would be nice
Following the suggestion of @sgouezel I am turning that into an auxiliary lemma for a future instance, which means that it should almost never be used, so dot notation will not be useful.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: `withDensity` of an s-finite measure is s-finite

nodes.body: You have an assumption that `f` is ae-measurable in your last lemma. Do you think it is really necessary? Sketch of proof without it (I haven't checked the details, so maybe I am saying nonsense): `μ.withDensity f` is absolutely continuous with respect to `μ`, which is absolutely continuous wrt to a finite measure rho. By Radon-Nikodym, one may write `μ.withDensity f` as a measure with density wrt rho, with some measurable density. And then you can apply your first lemma.

An issue I see is that we currently don't have Radon-Nikodym for `μ ≪ ν` without any assumption on `μ` (or even for `μ` s-finite). Right now we have it under the hypothesis of the two measures having a Lebesgue decomposition, and we have the existence of that decomposition only when they are *both* sigma-finite. My plan is to deduce the more general RN theorem from this PR (and several other PRs to come, proving among others the existence of the rho in your argument).

But do you agree that in the end the result should be true without any assumption? In this case, it could we worth adding a TODO in the docstring, and using a lemma name showing more clearly that it is an auxiliary statement towards a more general result. If you only use it with measurable functions, I am also not sure it's worth stating the auxiliary result for ae-measurable functions.

Yes I agree that it is true more generally! I will add a TODO and keep only the result for measurable instead of ae-measurable for now.
This auxiliary lemma will then be used to prove that every measure absolutely continuous with respect to an s-finite measure is s-finite, and at that point I'll come back to this to add an instance for s-finiteness of `μ.withDensity f`.

Pull request successfully merged into master.
